content.rendered:
Successful entrepreneurs create alliances with people who can help them with their strategies (the work they do to achieve their goals) and accomplishing the outcomes they want.

A strong alliance can be defined as a professional relationship where both parties benefit. Consider how alliances built around trust, motivating, and achieving goals can benefit both you and your team. Is there greater unity and productivity when there is trust? Are people more self-motivated when they understand how to form strategies, or plans, that achieve goals? Is performance higher when people are taught how to create and act on their own ideas? Yes, yes, and yes.

Examples of when energizing alliances can strengthen your performance:

  • Talking to your team about personal rank goals: Discuss your rank goals with identified downline leaders, share your ideas to help them with their rank goals (so you both can achieve your targeted rank), and create an even stronger plan together. Involving them in creating strategies for both of you makes it easier and more effective to promote your own goals with the help of others—without appearing insensitive or demanding.
  • Being emotionally steady: If you feel torn between family and work, energize alliances with your partner and children. Work out a schedule that works for you and your family. Include them in projects, and celebrate completion and success together. When your family knows what time is family time and what time is work time, everyone feels better cared for, and you perform better.

At this stage, trust is a tremendous help to you for two reasons:

  1. Trust, when established, will allow you to help and enroll people easier and faster.
  2. Trust will make you more effective. When you build your business using trust, you are more relaxed, confident, and sincere. All of these traits lead to better results and greater success.

Making this list of people is an early step in creating your strategy. Foster trust by considering questions like these as you meet with people:

  • What are they like?
  • What conversations have you had?
  • What do these people say?
  • What are their visions and dreams?
  • Have you scheduled a follow up with them, and have you kept this schedule?

Pay attention to people! Listen more than you speak. Have their concerns in mind. As people recognize your sincerity and helpfulness, they will trust you more. And creating trust is the first step in being a strong leader.

content.rendered:
Balance Your Work and Your Life

Organize a Plan

A balanced life is a sign of a confident, reliable leader.

Growing your business can feel overwhelming with so many commitments, priorities, and responsibilities to so many people. Working hard is great, but if it’s having a negative impact on you and/or your family, this is not healthy. You need balance. And balance is a sign of a good leader.

Here is a proven scheduling technique that creates balance and gives you control over your personal and professional life.

  • List your priorities. Include activities that help you meet physical, emotional, educational, and/or spiritual goals (e.g., exercise, family time, church/civic duties, etc.).
  • Schedule your priorities. On a calendar, schedule your daily and weekly priorities from the previous list.
  • Schedule time to work on your business. After your priorities have been scheduled, fill in other times when you will work on your business.

Create firm boundaries so you can devote quality time to your priorities. This way you have time for personal and family needs AND business building.

Mark complete when you have completed your schedule.

content.rendered:
Personal Development

Build Capacity

Build your capacity to succeed by regularly improving your skills.

Personal Development is an empowering tool for change.

Have you ever considered that confident people simply know how to do things well? And people who are in happy relationships have actually worked, really hard, to create these fulfilling relationships? If this is true, then confidence, happiness, rewarding relationships, and success in business can all be linked to your commitment to build your capacity by improving your own skills. This, then, begs the question: If you aren’t seeing success in a particular area of your life or business, what could you do differently, or what skills could you improve to create the success you want?

Personal Development improves:

  • self-confidence
  • perception of life (Are you an optimist or a pessimist? Do you blame others, or do you see how you need to improve somewhere?)
  • your contribution to and rewards in your life
  • how well you grow your business
  • your ability to handle stress and adversity
  • finances
  • relationships
  • health
  • attitude
  • your drive and motivation
Tips for Personal Development Time
  • Commit to at least 30 minutes of personal development every day. Put it on your daily calendar.
  • Spend 15 minutes learning more about the products. Use books, websites, videos, company resources, and personal experience.
  • Spend 15 minutes on Business/Personal Skills. Learn more about contacting, social media, leading a team, motivating others, parenting, time management, building trust, creating strategies, improving performance, etc.

The advantage of being where you are right now in your business is that you have access to so many resources created by people who’ve gone before you. They’ve essentially conducted years of research to identify effective methods. The smartest thing you can do is build your capacity and improve your skills by practicing what you learn from these people.

Take advantage of local events/trainings, conference calls, webinars, and classes. Energize alliances with other leaders by offering to help with events, and learn from these experiences.

Resources for improving your skills:

Use company websites and resources, YouTube, blogs, personal websites of other leaders, etc. to find resources about growing your business.

Find Live Trainings and Events
  • Visit your company websites to find live events. If specialty classes are taught in your area by corporate executives or other leaders and experts, attend at least one of these events each month.
  • Network and start creating alliances with other leaders. Energize these alliances by discussing a plan that is mutually beneficial to both of you (e.g., “You present at one of my classes, and I’ll help you with your webinar”).

Learn More
Learn More

content.rendered:
Closing a Class

Foster Trust

Organize a Plan

People like to buy, but they don’t like to be sold to. So guide them through the process of buying.

When it’s time to close, builders are sometimes apprehensive because they don’t want to pressure people, or they’re a little embarrassed to talk about the business opportunity.

But closing is much easier when you use a tested and proven system. If you present confidently and naturally, guiding people through the buying process, your volume and loyalty program enrollments will increase, and you will get more classes from classes.

Learn More

Step 1: Explain Kits and Available Product Options

Present kits that represent your class topic or the health and wellness goals of the class. Present two kits at two different price points, and explain what comes in each kit. Point out savings and benefits with each kit before price.

Most importantly, present kits and products that you are familiar with and that you are confident in because this will help you be more natural when explaining things. You’ll show greater confidence when you are talking about products that are familiar. And confidence sells.

Conversation Tips

Learn More

Learn More

Reward those who order at the class by using incentives to create urgency:

  • The incentive or free gift could be something small that the audience showed a lot of excitement about but is not included in the kits.
  • Generate even more excitement by personalizing the free gift to each individual in a one-on-one setting or based on comments and interest expressed during the class.
  • Offer the same gift you presented to the host.
  • Or provide two or three free gifts people can choose from.

Get creative, and have fun with this so the positivity and excitement is visible when you offer this “tonight-only special.”

Conversation Tips

Create confidence in ordering by explaining the return policy of the company. Keep it simple, and be sure to hit the major points so it is motivational and easy to process.

Conversation Tips

Step 2: Explain How to Order

Explain available ordering options: order forms, online, etc.

  • Make things simple by taking everyone through one enrollment option using one common form.
  • Later in the class, as you meet individually with people, you can discuss additional enrollment options: order forms, online, and even back office, if the situation feels right.
  • Be prepared with a computer or tablet connected to the internet or paper enrollment forms.
Step 3: Explain the Loyalty Program
  • Make it simple.
  • Explain the advantages and uses of the loyalty program
  • Ask for questions, and patiently clarify any confusion.

Conversation Tips

Learn More

Step 4: Introduce the Business Opportunity
  1. Explain that you are going to talk briefly about the business. (Keep it to 2-3 minutes.)
  2. Explain the two reasons you will talk about the business:
    • There is always one person there that is curious about the business.
    • People will want to share the products, so they might as well receive the benefits.
  3. In this 2 minutes, you have an opportunity to highlight WHY someone would want to work with you. What makes you different from every other distributor in your company? Also highlight a few key reasons why they would want to be part of your industry at this time, sharing accolades of the company.

Conversation Tips

  1. Briefly explain the benefits of sharing the product, and help people see how others use this opportunity.

Conversation Tips

Step 5: Offer Customer Service and Product Recommendations
  1. When helpful or requested, give recommendations on products you would select.
  2. As you meet individually with people, write down their goals, and create a list of products that will help with these goals.
  3. Total the cost for each goal separately so you can provide the most accurate information for them to decide.
  4. LET THEM CHOOSE. Provide two to three options to keep things simple, but allow them to choose any combination of products or kit they prefer.

Conversation Tips

Follow Up

After you’ve answered questions, resolved any concerns, and helped everyone set up their orders, start the process of following up by telling people when you will contact them to make sure their order arrived okay and that you will help them use the products so they get the best results.

Refer to Step 6 to see Conversation Tips for following up.

Learn More

Mark complete when you have the necessary handouts and you have practiced closing a class twice on your own and once with someone else—upline, mentor, at a class, etc.

content.rendered:
Following Up

Foster Trust

Following up builds trust because you are showing that you are reliable and you genuinely care about helping people.

One of the most exciting things in this business is following up with your contacts and your customers. Following up is not only a strong business strategy but also a perfect way to ensure people are cared for—which increases the likelihood that people will stay with you on your journey.

3 Tips for Following Up
  1. Personalize your follow up.
    As you help people place orders, make notes of what they ordered and why. Use this information when you follow up. This sincere, personal attention to your customers helps create repeat customers, referrals, and additional classes.

Conversation Tips

  1. Tell them when and why you’ll follow up.
    After discussing and helping with any questions, tell people when you’ll follow up and why. Build trust and be responsible by following up exactly when you say you will. The reason you’re following up should always be about the other person. This technique creates an easy “in” for next time, and it shows you genuinely care about them and their family.

Conversation Tips
Learn More

  1. Be professional and follow through.
    Show you are a trusted professional by following through with what, when, and why. If you say you’ll follow up “Tuesday,” do it. If something unavoidable comes up, follow up and let them know, and then reschedule the follow up.Use a desk calendar or your phone to schedule reminders for yourself. Forgetting may be understandable at times, but it doesn’t help your objectives—either for your contacts or your business.
When to Follow Up
  • Previous Contact Follow Up. Follow up with previous contacts to ask about their progress with products, how their family is doing, if they have any questions about the business, etc.

Conversation Tips

  • Reminder Follow Up. Follow up to remind people about incentives, rewards, promotions, etc. at an upcoming class. You can greatly increase attendance and participation at your classes if you help hosts follow up and remind people who are attending classes.

Conversation Tips

  • Q&A Follow Up. To identify ways to help, and to create possible opportunities, follow up with class attendees who had questions but didn’t order.

Conversation Tips

  • Product Order Follow Up. Follow up to inform or inquire about an order. People may have forgotten how to use products they learned about at a class, so this follow up can be very beneficial.

Conversation Tips

Resources to learn more about following up:
  • YouTube
  • upline or mentor
  • conference calls
  • webinars or online recordings on following up

Learn More

content.rendered:
Teaching a Class

Energize Alliances

Measure Progress and Render an Account

Energizing your alliances requires you to think as much for the wants of others as you do your own.

Classes are the best way for you to help people, find builders, and build your business because you simultaneously work on all of these with multiple people. They provide a really fun, comfortable atmosphere where you can get to know people and help them learn the benefits of these amazing products.

Classes may have a specific theme: Products for Back to School, Products for Massage and Spa, Basic Product Application, specific health goal, etc. Regardless of what the topic may be, classes are most effective for presenters and attendees when they are divided into a system that is easy to duplicate. Organize your classes into these basic parts, practice your presentation skills, and you will succeed.

Before the Class
Prepare and coordinate with your host.

Coordinate with hosts about contacting attendees to promote the class. Who is making contacts to promote the class, and what is the contacting schedule and message(s)?

So they are comfortable, prepare hosts in advance of the class. Review agendas, and discuss how to start the class: introducing you, explaining how they know you, their experiences with the products, etc.

Effectively promote your classes.

(You can find examples of promoting classes in Step 11 Troubleshooting under the topic “Low Class Attendance.”)

  • Advertise in advance and multiple times. For example, start two weeks out so people can plan for the class. Every 3-4 days, send out a new reminder message. Finish your schedule 2 days before the class.
  • Keep it fresh. Modify each message to keep communication fresh.
  • Emphasize the benefits. In each new reminder, focus on rewards, incentives, games, free gifts, samples, etc.
  • Personalize reminders. Strengthen working relationships by making reminders more personal: unique to a person’s specific health needs, specific to a particular event or situation, etc.
  • Spark interest and reward pre-class participation. Tell people about rewards for anyone who watches helpful and relevant recommended videos before coming to class. This can excite people and increase attendance. And it can help people be more informed when they attend so your classes are more productive and engaging.
Teaching the Class

To make sure people stay engaged and excited, keep presentation time to 30–35 minutes so you can use the rest of the time (15–30 minutes) to close and answer questions.

Part 1: Greet, Recognize, and Reward
  • Greet everyone individually. Learn and use people’s names to create connections. Learn why they are here so you can personalize the presentation and use this information as you help them at the end of class and when you follow up.
  • Strengthen your relationships with those who have helped you by thanking, recognizing, and rewarding the host and other presenters or anyone who has contributed to the class.
  • Incentivize future classes by displaying the benefits and rewards of hosting. This is done when you reward the host.

Learn More
Conversation Tips

  • Reward those participating in any contest or incentive program advertised for attending the class. For example, rewards could be for:
    • being among the first three to arrive.
    • bringing a friend.
    • responding to email requests reminding about the classes.
    • watching recommended videos before the class.
  • Introduce the class topic and agenda, explain the basic outline of the class, and introduce any incentives for participation.

Conversation Tips

Part 2: Learn About Your Audience, Introduce the Company and Products, Show How to Use Products
  1. Make your class presentations stronger by personalizing your presentation. Ask attendees “find-out” questions, and carefully read people so you can make adjustments to fit your audience.

Conversation Tips

  1. Build trust with your audience and link this trust to the products by explaining how the company is different and how these differences contribute to a superior product.

Conversation Tips

  1. Present the products for this class. Products could be seasonal or focused on a specific health purpose, your favorites, the most popular/common, or those requested by someone.Connect the products to your audience’s responses to the find-out questions at the beginning of class or from class-reminder email.

Conversation Tips

Allow people to experience the products, and explain how to use them:

  • Distributed/inhaled from a device
  • Ingested—mixed with food/water, in capsules, etc.
  • Topically—where and how frequently to apply for best/quickest results
  • Amounts to use
  • Any possible combinations
  • Fun ideas or recipes, etc.
  • Safety tips, etc.

NOTE: Use the products yourself, and become very familiar with the products you present at different classes so you can provide the best information and methods of application.

Learn More

Part 3: Close the Class

(Learn more about how to close in Step 8: Closing a Class.)

  • Pass out any rewards or incentives for participation you established at the beginning of the class.
  • Thank everyone for their attendance and participation.
  • Discuss the opportunity for free product/gift if they order or sign up to host a class.
  • Answer any questions about specific products, how to apply them, etc.
  • Introduce the benefits of the loyalty program. (You’ll learn how to do this in the next step.)
  • Introduce the business opportunity. (You’ll learn how to do this in the next step.)
  • Make any product or kit recommendations.
  • Explain different pricing or kit options available.
  • Help people place their order.

Use company media, YouTube videos of other leaders, etc. as resources to see examples of people teaching classes. Practice what you see. Remember, keep it simple! This helps you and those attending. In the event that an attendee wants to enroll to build, seeing a simple class will help them feel confident that they too can teach classes.

Schedule your first three classes with the help of your mentor or upline. Have these people help you teach, and learn from them.

Learn More

4. Identify Your Allies

Internal and External Allies are people or organizations that will help you achieve your selected outcome. You’ll learn how to energize these alliances (or working relationships with your allies) in Innovation 4.

  • Internal Allies: people inside your organization or team

  • External Allies: people outside your organization
    This can include government officials, FDA, medical experts, people who give testimonials, guest speakers, your bank, print shops for brochures, post office, etc. (e.g., people who give testimonials add support and authenticity to your classes).

Who are your INTERNAL allies? Think of at least three.

Who are your EXTERNAL allies? Think of at least three.

content.rendered:
Organize a Plan for Innovation

1. Identify Critical Success Factors

Critical Success Factors are the totally necessary actions that should always be focused on in order to achieve the outcome you have selected. For example, if your selected outcome is to improve the attendance and effectiveness of your classes, Critical Success Factors might include:

  • early communication,
  • sending out reminders,
  • making sure your invitation is compelling,
  • making assignments and following up to make sure team members are prepared,
  • organizing the presentation so it’s smooth and effective, and
  • following up quickly after the class.

What are the Critical Success Factors you need to focus on to achieve your selected outcome?

Ideas

Learn More

2. Allocate the Vital Few Resources: Time, Money, and Communication

Time, money, and communication are the vital resources necessary to put your plan into action. How will you organize your time to ensure success? How much money do you want to devote? What methods—type and frequency—of communicating with others will you use to make sure your plan has the resources to succeed?

Learn More

How much time and money will you devote, and how frequently will you communicate to achieve your selected outcome?

3. Lay Out a Change Path

Your change path is a step-by-step plan of action—different from what you have been doing—to achieve your selected outcome. What are you going to do first, second, and third?

For example, if you want to increase enrollments, important elements on your change path might include identifying all the steps of holding a class, organizing them in a step-by-step process, and then identifying where change is needed to increase enrollments: is it getting more people to the class, is it in the presentation, or is in the follow up?

If you want to boost leader motivation, your change path might look like this:

  1. Identify three challenges my leaders are facing.
  2. Teach them possible ways to overcome these challenges.
  3. Regularly check in with each of them to see how they are progressing.

If you want to increase volume, here is a possible change path:

  1. Identify sources of leads (internet, classes, expos, and sharing).
  2. Make personal contact and listen to discover the true needs of each person you are working with.
  3. Find out how you can help.
  4. Share products, and follow up.

Learn More

Organize a Plan for Innovation

Create a strategy to improve, and build commitment.

Why Organize a Plan for Innovation?
Are you spending a lot of time on less-productive activities?

The plan you organize is the bridge between the direction you want to take and the actions necessary to see the desired results. Make sure your work is linked to desired outcomes and goals and not just keeping you busy.

Do you and your team members think that having a well-organized plan or strategy is an important part of your work?

Organizing a plan for innovation is the beginning of genuine commitment to actually do what it will take to get better results. Plans also increase efficiency so you are more successful and feel less burned out.

Do you and your team have more contention and frustration than you would like?

Organizing a plan for innovation unifies people, identifies and allocates resources necessary for plans to succeed, and helps everyone focus to make sure desired outcomes are achieved.

Do several of your team members lack initiative? Do they often wait to be instructed instead of taking control themselves?

Check to see if these people have plans to support their goals. Organizing a plan for innovation boosts leader motivation. Plans enable people to move away from waiting and being acted upon (passive) and instead become people who act (proactive)—or people who take action for themselves or their team.

What Is Organize a Plan for Innovation?

Organizing for innovation maps out a strategy for turning your ideas into actions and actually accomplishing something better! It is the way you plan to accomplish your defined direction and selected outcomes. Strategy is a crucial part of the leadership system because it motivates you to face the reality that success will require commitment from you and other people. This is one of your most important leadership tasks. Teach the members of your team to develop strategy as a means of building commitment, self-motivation, and initiative. When people see, step by step, how a leadership plan to innovate is organized, they will be more committed to participate.

Leadership Principle

Assess Your Current Strategy
Every morning review what you consider to be the most important tasks for you to accomplish that day. Review how you use your time, and determine if you are spending more time on the most important or most critical factors or if you spend time on less-important things.

Create a New Strategy

content.rendered:
Define the Direction (Part 2)

How to Define the Direction

Strong leaders in business understand how to innovate! The following three powerful tools of innovation—Observing, Questioning, and Associating—are used to first create vision and then help create a plan that produces real results, so good ideas are not wasted.

STEP 1: Observing

Being able to honestly and accurately observe your situation is how you begin to identify ways to improve and succeed.

To observe, or assess your situation, consider these questions:

  • What is the current task or goal facing you and your downline?
  • How have you observed a clear team direction affecting productivity or motivation?
  • What current projects, trainings, classes, or new contact relationships would be more successful with a clearer direction and better teamwork?

Observe your team’s functions, communication, interactions, trainings, classes, etc., and make a mental note of areas where better teamwork and a clear direction are needed.

STEP 2: Questioning

Questioning means exploring what you’re currently doing and what you want to do better. It is the beginning of identifying strategies you can use to increase success. Ask questions like, “What did we do last month/quarter?” or “What would our team be like if we…?”
When people do not share ideas or ask questions, you do not have a functioning team; you have a group of individuals working on their own agendas. True teamwork is where success is found and multiplied. Good leaders LISTEN! You might have a good idea, but your builders and leaders might have discovered a GREAT idea.

Consider these questions as you begin defining your direction.

  • What are the results you are currently achieving with your business?
  • What have you done to produce these results?
  • What trends in performance can you see in yourself and with your leaders over the last month/quarter/year?
  • What have other similar builders/teams chosen to do?
  • What outcomes will demonstrate the improvement you want?
  • With all of this information in mind, what direction should you go?

How to Energize Your Team and Your Alliances

Step 1
Energize your team by helping them feel successful.

Accomplish this by:

  • reviewing your selected outcomes.
  • discussing what everyone can do so everyone succeeds and asking individuals to accept assignments to help.

Energize your alliances with others.

Energize alliances by using three tools of innovation:

Everyone in this business has been told about the importance of networking—or getting out there and meeting lots of people. If you haven’t already, consider something new about networking. Networking means communicating with many different people about what you do and learning what others do. Then when there is compatibility or a shared interest, it is possible to transform the acquaintance into an alliance where both parties can help each other. Learning from others and benefiting both parties is far more effective than just meeting a lot of people.

Foster Trust and Build Teamwork (Part 2)

Here are five trust factors—actions you can apply to create and foster trust with your team. Duplicate success by learning these traits well so you can teach them to your team.

TRUST FACTORS

1. Integrity, Responsibility, and Accountability

People trust you when they see you being responsible—following through, being consistent, staying committed, and taking responsibility for mistakes made or assignments forgotten and then improving. If you have integrity, that means you keep your promises, respect people by being punctual, report to people what you intend to do and then do it, etc. This is related to being accountable—taking personal responsibility and honestly accounting for your actions.

Build trust in others by giving credit to other people for your success. Build trust by kindly inviting others to fully participate in meetings, accepting their ideas when appropriate, giving assignments with due dates, and recognizing effort and results.

How will you improve your integrity, responsibility, and accountability?

Ideas

2. Emotional Control

People trust you, follow you, and invest in teamwork when you exhibit a steady, reliable, and positive attitude with more self-motivation and enthusiasm and less anxiety and stress. Eliminate anger.

How will you improve emotional control?

Ideas

3. Self-Motivation

People trust you when they see you doing something extra to achieve the results you want. Build trust by finding one more contact than you need or scheduling one additional class a week, instead of doing the bare minimum. Build trust in your team by asking them to be self-motivated and do a little more than the least amount required.

How will you become more self-motivated?

Ideas

4. Interpersonal Skills

Someone with interpersonal skills understands the difference between a high-quality and low-quality relationship. Encourage high-quality, trusting relationships by polishing your communication skills and getting to know people well enough that you remember important dates or milestones in their lives and learn what motivates them individually.

How will you improve your interpersonal skills?

content.rendered:
Contacting

Build Capacity

True empowerment comes when you are in control. Building capacity by improving your skills gives you control.

Whether contacting people is easy or difficult for you, contacting is necessary. So instead of viewing contacting with fear and apprehension, see it as an opportunity to grow and explore. You’ll be surprised when you put yourself out there!

The easiest place to start is with the list you made of people you want to contact. To make contacting a little easier, start looking at any contact as an opportunity to help this person, either with products or an opportunity.

By genuinely caring about others enough to learn about them, you are establishing a strong foundation of trust. When people feel they can trust you, they are more likely to listen, investigate the products, attend or host classes, join your team, and perform at higher levels.

As you read about the following tips to improve contacting, visualize yourself applying these skills to contacting people in different situations: friends, colleagues, family, a stranger in a pharmacy, contacts from classes, etc.

Let’s get started!

5 Tips to Improve Contacting
  1. Have a positive attitude.
    We are naturally drawn to happy, smiling, positive people. A positive attitude puts you at ease and allows your thoughts to function faster and more efficiently. Expressing a positive attitude while talking with people communicates that you are enjoying the conversation, which encourages people to talk more. And you want other people to talk so you can listen and identify ways you can help them.
  2. Ask questions to generate curiosity.
    Questions are your greatest tool when contacting. Questions generate curiosity—curiosity you have in other people and their curiosity in you. Use questions to relax the conversation (e.g., “What do you do for a living?” “How is your family?”). Listen carefully so this curiosity can grow into conversation that allows you to become more familiar with people and learn how to help them.
  3. Identify common interests.
    Common interests help conversations to flow more naturally. Common interests help people feel comfortable with opening up more. If you don’t feel like you know very much about this person, ask more questions, and look for common ground: hobbies, interests, health concerns (and the products), careers (and the opportunity), skills, etc. NOTE: Pay attention to topics that are linked to your business, but this is not the time to talk about the business. It is time to generate trust and genuine interest in this person so you can better help him or her when it is time to introduce products or the business opportunity.
  4. Focus on others, not yourself.
    Feelings of discomfort come when you are too focused on yourself: your agenda, your needs, your business, etc. Trust comes when you focus on the needs of others. When you do introduce the products or opportunity, the trust you have established will lead to a better response. So if you feel nervous, uncomfortable, or like you’re imposing on their time, put the focus on them, and let them share valuable information with you.
  5. Have confidence.
    Confidence is not arrogance. People are drawn to those who are confident. Arrogance drives people away. You know the products and business are amazing. Have confidence in them. Use this confidence to convey your genuine interest in people and your desire to help them.
Resources for additional tips on contacting:
  • YouTube videos shared by other company leaders
  • your upline or mentor
  • team or conference calls, webinars, or online recordings on contacting

content.rendered:
Daily & Weekly Habits for Success

Organize a Plan

Self-discipline, confidence, hard work, and success can be habit forming.

Forming good habits gives you confidence in your abilities and control over your own success. These habits will help you be more effective at organizing strategies to achieve your goals.

There are several network marketing resources (trainings, worksheets, checklists, etc.) available to help you organize your daily and weekly habits. Here are suggested actions you can take to develop better habits and improve results in sales, leadership, mindset, and more for any resource or system you use.

DAILY
  • Do 30 minutes of personal development.
    (You’ll learn more about personal development later on in Jump Start.)

    • 15 minutes improving your knowledge about the product.
    • 15 minutes on improving you: skills for presenting, contacting, time management, parenting, mentoring, strategies in the 6i Catalyst app, etc.
  • Contact at least 2 people.
  • Follow up with at least 2 people.
  • Call upline leader/mentor. Quick calls to touch base, review progress, and discuss improvements so you are working efficiently and with purpose.
  • Eliminate or work on eliminating one obstacle.
WEEKLY
Review and Assess
  • Upline/Downline Communication
    Touch base with your upline and your downline to review progress and discuss changes.
  • Product Trends
    Watch for trends in products (e.g., Are certain products more popular at different times of year, around holidays, etc.? How can you take advantage of this to increase enrollments or loyalty program enrollments?).
  • Work Trends
    Identify trends in your work. For example, what are you doing that is working—more classes scheduled, higher closing rate, more loyalty program enrollments, etc.?
  • Classes
    Prepare for any upcoming classes: reminders and advertising, materials, coordinate with the host or other presenters, rewards or incentives, etc.
  • Training
    Attend or prepare for trainings, workshops, conference calls, convention, webinars, etc. Do you need materials? Do you have questions for other leaders?
  • Identify obstacles, and work to remove them.
    Identify causes. What needs to be done to eliminate obstacles: extra training, extra study, help from another leader, etc.?
Change and Improve

Select at least one thing you want to improve this week:

  • Contacting
  • Following Up
  • Class Presentation
  • Closing
  • Teaching Team
  • Customer Service
  • Leadership
  • Loyalty Program Enrollments
Define a New Direction, and Commit Yourself and Your Team

Write down a new goal or outcome you want to focus on.

  • List the reasons for this goal.
  • List how you can encourage and include team members’ participation with this same goal/outcome so you are working together to achieve something great.

content.rendered:
Setting Goals

Define the Direction

A goal without a clearly defined direction is just a wish.

Goals can challenge you and inspire growth and improvement. Setting and achieving goals helps you realize you can accomplish more than you thought possible. Goals can be large (“hit new rank in three months”) or more moderate (“contact three new people this week”). What is important is the growth that occurs as you work toward your goals.

It can be easy to see your goals or where you want to go. The challenge is to navigate how you get there. To help you practice setting goals and creating the strategies necessary to achieve them, this section will walk you through two goals necessary for every successful network marketing entrepreneur: financial and rank goals.

Be sure to choose a realistic date when you want to achieve these goals. Hold yourself accountable, and commit. Remember, it’s about growth, and you grow when you challenge yourself and then work hard to meet that challenge!

Here’s a simple checklist to help you shape good goals.

“Good Goals” Checklist
  • Goals should be reachable—with effort—so you do not become discouraged.
  • Goals should challenge you so you are excited, growing, and improving.
  • Goals should represent multiple areas of your business: enrollments, volume growth, rank, classes, contacts, income, etc.
  • Goals should be set daily, weekly, and monthly. This variety in timeline keeps you motivated and progressing.
  • Goals should be reported. Reporting your goals to someone (mentor, spouse, friend in the company) increases your level of commitment and execution.

Learn More

The more specific you make your financial goals and rank goals, the more clear your path will be.

Setting Financial Goals
  1. Set a financial goal.
    Select a date a few months ahead, and decide how much money you want to be earning by that date.
  2. Create a monthly plan.
    To know what you need to do each month to reach your financial goal, work backward, setting mini goals for each preceding month.For example, if you enrolled in May and you want to be making $2,500 a month by September, work backward from September and make a plan for each month. Your plan might look like this:

    • September— $2,500/month
    • August — $2,300/month
    • July — $2,000/month
    • June — $1,700/month

    Working backward like this helps you identify what each monthly goal needs to be.

    Use this information to make your weekly plans (e.g., to make $1,700 in June, you need to be doing $425/week, which might mean you need two classes a week if you close around $225 per class). Adjust your work—contacting, classes, following up, etc.—accordingly to maintain this goal schedule.

  3. Learn from others and from your own experience.
    As you are setting goals and creating your schedule, ask your upline leaders, mentor, or others who are succeeding if your goal plan is strong. Compare your model to theirs, and see if you need to make adjustments—speed things up or slow things down. Use this information to improve your experience. You increase confidence when you can control outcomes, like achieving goals, so learn to create schedules that challenge you but that are clear and attainable so you build confidence as you achieve success.
Setting Rank Goals

Learn about ranks from your mentor or upline leaders. Then use the same process you used to set financial goals to set rank goals.

Choose a date a few months ahead, and decide what rank you want to reach by that date. Then work backward to determine what achievements you need each preceding month to reach your rank goal.

For example, select the rank of Level 7 by September, and work backward from there. You’ll likely need to be a solid Level 6 rank by August. This means you’d need to be at least a weak Level 6 in July and work to be a solid Level 6 by August.

Here is an example of a rank goal schedule:

  • September—Level 7 (weak or solid, but you hit your rank goal!)
  • August—Level 6 (solid)
  • July—Level 6 (hit Level 6 for the first time, so it is weak)
  • June—Level 5 (solid)
  • May—Level 5 (weak Level 5, so give yourself another month to strengthen this rank)

Once you have made financial and rank goals, feel proud of yourself! This is a huge step!

Learn More

content.rendered:
Identify Your Purpose

Define the Direction

“Why” is the pinnacle of “what” you do and “how” you do it.

Identifying the reason you are doing something—or your “why”—is a powerful step toward defining the direction you want to go as you move forward in your business. Whether your purpose is based on finances or helping others, your purpose begins to shape how you think, which changes how you act.

Author Simon Sinek has popularized the idea of finding your “why.” He said people are more likely to be drawn to “why” you are doing something than they are “what” or “how” you do it. Knowing why you are doing something is a powerful motivator that keeps you focused when faced with challenges and gives you a direction as you map out strategies to succeed.

Learn More

How to Identify Your Purpose

Two activities can help you pinpoint your purpose.

  1. Create a vision board.
    To help you visualize your goals, make a vision board by collecting pictures, quotes, or objects that represent your personal desires and attaching them to a poster board. These goals and desires might be emotional, financial, physical, etc. Be creative, have fun, and make something that uniquely represents you and what you want for yourself.
  2. Ask yourself “why.”
    Honestly answering the following questions will help you uncover your true purpose. Write down your answer to the first question, and then use this answer to complete the next question, exploring why your answer is important to you. Follow this same pattern as you continue through the rest of the questions.

    1. Why did I decide to share these products?
      (e.g., “I want to make extra money to help my family” or “I want to share natural health alternatives.”)
    2. Why is this so valuable to me?
      (e.g., “It is so valuable to me to make extra money to help my family because I want to feel peace at home away from financial burdens.”)
    3. Why is this essential to me?
      (e.g., “It is essential to me to feel peace in my family, free from financial burdens, so our family can be closer and focus more on positive things.”)
    4. How would your life change if you succeeded at accomplishing this?
      (e.g., “If our family was closer and free from financial burdens, we would argue less, feel more love, be able to help others, and experience and enjoy life.”)
    5. What are you willing to commit to in order to achieve this?
      (e.g., “I’m willing to commit to changing or improving a little each day; I’m willing to commit to a project to see it through until the end; I’m willing to commit to finding the best way of doing things.”)

Learn More

content.rendered:
Who to Contact First

Organize a Plan

Foster Trust

Create plans centered on trust, and people will trust your plan.

Now it’s time to start thinking about people you might be able to help. Some people you know might be interested in the products; others might be interested in new financial opportunities. Start making a list of 50 or 100 people, and keep track of…

  • why these people might be interested (products or business),
  • the best way to contact them,
  • when you contact them,
  • what their response is, and
  • when you’re going to follow up.

Your list can include people you already know and people you meet doing business. These contacts might include someone you meet when teaching a class, anyone you share a sample with, or people who express interest in your social media posts about the products or business.

Think about contacting businesses who might be interested in the products: medical centers, spas, dietitians, health food stores, yoga studios, style and beauty businesses, holistic or natural health specialists, chiropractors, physical therapists, etc. Think creatively about any businesses that could benefit from your product. Your ideas may never have occurred to them and could lead to very productive relationships.

You’ll learn more about approaching people later on in Jump Start, but remember these tips as you begin making contact:

Keep it natural.

Ask a lot of questions, and do more listening than talking. Don’t be pushy. Talk about the products or business when the topic comes up naturally.

Build on common interests.

If someone mentions work, confidently share what you do and why it works for you. If a friend talks about an illness, share products that can help.

Be genuine.

Be warm and friendly and always sincere. Ultimately, your goal should be to help, and you can only do that when you listen attentively to another’s needs or concerns instead of pushing your own agenda.

content.rendered:
Secrets of Reading People Accurately

Foster Trust

Pay attention to people, and they’ll pay attention to you.

Reading people—being able to identify and utilize verbal and nonverbal cues—will help you improve your performance and results because it can help you make instant adjustments to classes, sales presentations, and team trainings. These adjustments can make a huge difference.

There are a few fundamentals to be aware of as you improve your ability to read people:
  • Get to know people. Start by listening and observing—skills you’ll use constantly when reading people.
  • Ask them questions, and learn to pay attention to both their response and possible underlying cues: comfort or discomfort in their voice.
  • Watch for patterns. A person may fidget in a chair because the chair is uncomfortable, not because they are not interested in what you are saying. So watch for patterns or multiple cues—take your cues from their words, tone, body language, and face. Is this person only fidgeting in her chair, or is she fidgeting, avoiding eye contact, and tapping her fingers?

The following sections will help you discover how to pay special attention to body language and emotions when reading people, exhibit confidence when presenting, and determine if people are in sync with you.

Observe Body Language Cues

Most cues come from body language. Watch for positive signs that people are in agreement. Negative signs suggest you need to change something in your message or delivery.

The following describes what kind of body language to watch for.

Appearance

What are people wearing?

  • A business suit may indicate they are all business. Speak and present professionally.
  • An exercise outfit might represent their focus on health and wellness. Present associated products.
  • Jeans and a t-shirt might indicate a more laid-back personality focusing on comfort. Discuss how products can be shared casually, in natural settings.
Posture
  • Sitting up straight may indicate confidence.
  • Slouching might possibly represent indifference or a lack of confidence.
  • Leaning forward often suggests interest.
  • Crossed arms and legs, more often than not, indicate defensiveness and indifference.

Positive or comfortable body language cues suggesting you are on the right track include…

  • leaning forward
  • relaxed limbs that are at their sides
  • eye contact
  • smiling that does not look forced or gritted

Negative body cues suggesting you may need to make changes include…

  • leaning away from you
  • crossed arms and legs
  • limbs that are moving (nervous tapping of fingers or legs, picking at fingernails or cuticles, etc.)
  • looking away when talking
  • lip biting

People engage in these nervous behaviors because they take their mind off what’s bothering them and ease their tension.

Read Emotions
Eyes

The eyes provide an ocean of information. While training or presenting at a class, do people’s eyes follow you? Are their eyes inquisitive, expressing excitement and enjoyment, or are they empty and looking elsewhere, expressing boredom or confusion?

Facial Expression

Emotions can be etched on our faces. Crows feet or lines at the outward corner of the eyes indicate smiling/laughing and can be a sign of optimism and a positive personality. Frown lines around the mouth may suggest someone is more pessimistic, stressed, or worried.

How to Exhibit Confidence

Want to take charge when presenting? The brain is hardwired to equate power with the amount of space we take up. Use your posture to express confidence in yourself and your message. Stand tall, don’t slouch, and move to different places in the room and see if people’s eyes follow you.

How to Determine if People Are in Sync With You

When people mimic your body language, this is a good sign that they are synced with you and interested in what you are presenting. When you cross or uncross your legs, watch to see if they copy you. Tilt your head, and watch if they mirror you by tilting their head the same way. Mirroring is something we do unconsciously when we are in sync with another person. It is a positive sign that things are going well. This can be useful knowledge when negotiating or persuading others.

Learn More

content.rendered:
The Best Ways to Build Confidence

Organize a Plan

If you fail to plan, you plan to fail.

Having confidence doesn’t mean you have to know everything or be good at everything. Being confident means you have a level of self-awareness that you can do things well. And things you can’t do well right now, you have confidence you can learn.

Building a network marketing business can feel overwhelming because so much is new and unfamiliar. Don’t worry. This is part of the exciting process of developing new skills and testing ideas to increase confidence.

Read the following characteristics of confident people, and consider areas where you want to improve.

Confident people…
  • Regularly stimulate brain growth by periodically choosing interesting, stimulating, or challenging activities.
  • Appreciate that mental activities promote physical health, and good health habits promote mental alertness.
  • Tend to be optimistic and bounce back fairly quickly after experiencing adversity in their lives.
  • Accept responsibility for their discouragement but will use the help of other people to resolve negative moods.
  • Are more likely to change their lifestyle than use medication to resolve emotional problems.
  • Seek out those who encourage, and avoid people who discourage.
To start building confidence, use these self-talk statements about yourself:
  • I can do this.
  • I am getting better.
  • When I pay attention, I learn.
  • I have a great brain.

Confident people don’t criticize themselves and instead use positive self-talk statements like these. Recognizing what they do well, they assess areas that can use improvement and then create a plan to improve.

Start building confidence by improving your mental abilities.

Improve Your Memory

Developing an effective memory helps build confidence. Most people who have good memories use the following techniques.

Associating

When you want to remember something, associate it with something you already know or something that will help you remember. For example, you may associate a person’s name with your favorite movie star because they resemble each other. This is a great way to remember the names of people you meet.

Metacognition

Metacognition sounds really sciency, right? Basically, it means “thinking about how you think” or reflective thinking or introspection. Metacognition helps you improve confidence because it helps you understand how you learn, what you learn, and how you can improve.

Confident people know how they best learn—by seeing, doing or experiencing, hearing, etc.—and they use this knowledge to develop their skills. For example, how do you learn? If you learn best by doing, do you look for and create opportunities to try new things, or do you shy away from things that are unfamiliar? If you avoid learning opportunities, how are you going to learn and improve—and gain confidence?

Categorizing

You retain and recall more if you organize the information you want to memorize into categories. A simple example of this is a grocery store. Related items are organized together. Can you imagine shopping if food was scattered randomly throughout the store? It would take forever. Memory is similar. When you organize the ideas you want to remember, you retrieve them easier later. For example, categorize products by how they are used, by their place of origin, or by related health-promoting qualities, etc.

Build Confidence by Being Optimistic

People who are confident are usually optimistic about themselves and their lives.

Optimism creates better brain activity and optimal thought and creativity. Optimism increases confidence because you get more out of your experiences when you are optimistic.

Are you an optimistic person or a pessimistic person?
  • Optimists recognize mistakes when they are made, but they also recognize what they can do and how they contribute to positive outcomes. Pessimists blame themselves when bad things happen and contribute positive outcomes to things other than themselves.
  • Optimists see bad events as temporary and good events as having long-term causes. Pessimists think the opposite.
  • Optimists look at bad events as caused by something specific. Pessimists believe that bad things affect every area of life and have universal causes.
  • Optimistic beliefs help us bounce back from adversity and act to change the situation. Pessimistic beliefs lead to depression, passivity, and feelings of hopelessness.
How to overcome pessimism:
Step 1

Become aware of your beliefs about the causes of adversity. When you experience adversity—small or large—record the event.

EXAMPLE: You don’t enroll anyone at a class. What do you believe is the cause?

Step 2

Pay attention to what you tell yourself about the event or the belief you have. Replace pessimism with optimism.

EXAMPLE: If you fail to enroll people at a class, do you fall into despair, feeling hopeless? Or do you identify what you did well and areas that need improvement?

Step 3

Record the consequence of your beliefs. Your feelings, for example, are consequences of your stated beliefs. Include how you felt and what you did in response to the event. Eliminate pessimistic thoughts and reactions, and create a plan to improve, including necessary change, developing new skills, getting help from others, etc.

EXAMPLE: “If I feel (recognize the consequence of my belief) that this failed class is temporary and I know what I can do better, the consequences are that I can feel confident in my ability to overcome setbacks by being creative, working hard, learning from others, and improving myself.”

Learn More

content.rendered:
Attitude Sells

Measure Progress

A plan is the difference between wanting something and accomplishing it.

Attitude is a belief that controls behavior that produces results. The better and stronger the attitude, the greater the results. Many top sales people believe sales are 90% attitude and 10% skill. So one of the most important tools to improve sales is to master your attitude. Being in control of your attitude puts you in charge of whatever you want to accomplish. And controlling your attitude improves your confidence and how you feel about yourself!

There are eight components to mastering your attitude.

1. Envisioning

Envisioning is seeing what you want for and from yourself—what you want to become.

Here is how envisioning is applied to sales:

  1. First, think about what you currently do when selling.

    EXAMPLE    : “I think about all the times I failed to share product or enroll someone and get down on myself and start to feel hopeless.”
  2. Second, think about what you want for yourself.

    EXAMPLE    : I want to focus on what I can learn from a sales opportunity whether it’s good or bad.
  3. Third, think about why you want this.

    EXAMPLE    : I want to be able to control my thoughts and feelings and use this control to improve my next sales opportunity.

Learn More

2. Developing Strategy

A strategy is a step-by-step plan (think road map) you use to control your thoughts and attitude. Strategies are essential because they allow you to test ideas and find what works—keeping the methods that work and eliminating those that don’t.

Strategies to control your attitude include having a vision for what you want (focus on what you want to BE, not do), the steps to try something and test yourself to see what you can do, and then steps called “behavior in situations” to ensure you are applying your strategy in the situations where you want to control your attitude—attitude during classes, when closing a class, when working with a mentor, when mentoring others, when work is frustrating, etc.

3. Creating Change

Without change, we don’t progress. Improvement and success are evidence of change. So change is a good thing. Change is harder if you resist it, think only others should do it, make excuses for yourself, or fear it. Instead, see change as a friend or tool that adds value to your life. See situations where you need to change as positive opportunities to improve, and take control to become the person you want to be. Create change by identifying what you need and want to change, and then hold yourself accountable for carrying out your strategy for making these changes.

For example, reporting recent performance to a mentor can be viewed as an opportunity to measure your level of responsibility and learn new things from his or her input and observations instead of viewing these reports as someone checking up on you.

4. Focus

Success increases when you improve your ability to concentrate on what you want for and from yourself. The more focused you are on goals for attitude and sales, the more your brain creates new and exciting ideas. And when you focus, you are more likely to stick to your plan and carry it out, which increases success.

For example, if you want to improve closing rates at classes, while preparing for each class, focus on your goal: “I want to be more calm and confident so I can enroll more people at classes I teach.”

5. Positivity

Positive emotions motivate and focus your efforts. Negative emotions distract and distress. Motivation to achieve comes from positive emotions like confidence, security, happiness, enthusiasm, excitement, and fun. Fear of failure comes from anxiety, worry, frustration, anger, duress, discouragement, and sadness.

The good news is, you can control what you feel by applying emotional control in four ways.

  1. Be aware of yourself and take responsibility for what you feel.
    “I’m just feeling stressed right now, so I need to calm down a bit and not take my emotions out on other people.”
  2. Be in control by having consideration for others.
    “What she said was a little offensive, but perhaps she is feeling frustrated and overwhelmed, so I don’t need to feel offended.”
  3. Be optimistic (or learn how).
    “I don’t understand how to do something, but I’m excited about the possibilities of learning new things.”
  4. Reframe your worries to be positive and constructive.
    “Things didn’t go as planned, but I learned what I can do better next time.”
6. Motivational Control

You gain motivational control over your attitude by frequently thinking about two things:

  1. results you achieve and the reward for achieving them, and
  2. standards of performance you wish to demonstrate.

For example, gain motivational control over your attitude by identifying your standards for closing rates at your classes and the reward for achieving them. Let your standards motivate you.

7. Completion

Completion can help you identify your priorities because you typically complete what is important to you. Once you’ve thought about what you typically complete, assess if these priorities are in line with what you want for and from yourself. Are they contributing to your goals? Complete projects that help you to achieve. Eliminate moments when you fail to complete what you started. Improve by setting goals to complete more tasks you start.

8. Rewarding Yourself

True rewards come with the strong sense of satisfaction you feel when new results are achieved, the confidence from knowing your abilities and not feeling like you have to prove anything to anyone, and the quiet excitement from continued success. These rewards give higher closing rates, sales records, and increased income more meaning. To improve yourself, reward yourself. Reward yourself with fun or enjoyable rewards for acting as you have planned or for achieving behavior goals. Be honest with rewards, and apply them only after improving some part of the components to master your attitude.

Learn More

content.rendered:
Identify and Develop Great Leaders

Energize Alliances

Exceptional leadership is measured by the success of the team.

Finding the right people to lead teams is a powerful tool you can use to accelerate the growth of your business. People who listen and do what you tell them are good. People who create on their own are better.

Use these ten characteristics to identify good leaders or develop builders into self-motivated, high-performing leaders.
  1. Communication
    How well and how often does this person communicate with others? Is it too much, is it not enough, is it distracting?
  2. Temperament
    How reactive or calm is this person around others? Is this person patient, a good listener, and willing to gather information before making a judgement?
  3. Perspective
    How positive or negative is this person around others? Is this person reasonably optimistic, complimentary, and encouraging, or is he or she critical, demeaning, and blaming?
  4. Work Habits
    How diligent and focused is this person when working with others? Can this person focus on the work and avoid distractions? Can this person also keep others focused, without seeming to be superior or overly critical?
  5. Responsibility
    Does this person respect due dates and keep promises to others? When given assignments, does this person complete it on time or communicate why the due date is not respected? Is there enough integrity involved so that a person’s work means dependability and responsibility?
  6. Mindset
    How successful is this person in both forming individual opinions and being willing to listen to others? Is there respect for each person’s perspective and value shown for the good ideas of others?
  7. Honesty
    How does this person display honesty and integrity when associating with others? Is this person able to be honest about him- or herself, and does he or she display values like respect for property, other people’s possessions, and the role of time?
  8. Teaching
    Does this person have a demonstrated desire and ability to learn and teach or share with others what they learn?
  9. Competence
    Can this person effectively use technology to communicate? Does this person understand the business? Is this person familiar with the products, and does he or she stay updated on newly released products?
  10. Vision
    Great leaders take people to places they have never been. Does this person have a sense of vision of future possibilities and then communicate these possibilities to those he or she leads?

These characteristics can help you identify people who already have leadership skills, but you can also use them to train any of your builders and help them become high-performing leaders.

Learn More

content.rendered:
Mentoring is Crucial for Success

Foster Trust and Build Teamwork Energize Alliances

The power to motivate and influence others is rooted in your ability to first earn trust and then teach others to create trust.

One skill of a leader is to be a mentor to other people. Mentoring speeds how fast and how well people learn and perform. Even the best athletes and musicians learn better with a mentor or coach. Being and working with a mentor increases diligent habits, and these habits lead to improved performance.

A mentor is someone who works with others to discuss ideas or strategies, measure progress, offer suggestions to create or correct direction, identify solutions to challenges, and motivate. Mentors improve how people view themselves.

Mentors create a growth mindset. This means they may help to identify potential causes of problems, frustrations, or discouragement, but they primarily focus attention and effort on solutions and progress (growth)—not on problems or excuses.

Start developing yourself into an influential mentor by considering how you can adopt these principles all mentoring should be based on:
  1. developing hope,
  2. making sure each person feels better after a conversation than before,
  3. teaching how humility and accuracy lead to strengths because they allow for better learning and improvement,
  4. understanding the power of the context or situation in which each person lives, so you can accurately help people optimistically focus on hope and future possibilities,
  5. teaching how trust, integrity, and commitment are the triggers of growth and change, and
  6. helping people connect positive emotions with change and action plans.

Understanding people can help you be a better mentor. Learn how to gather information about the people you work with, their situations, and how they view them. The better you understand people on your team, the better you can help them.

Learn about…
  1. the people who will help or hinder change—family, friends, colleagues, etc.,
  2. the person’s pressures and stresses he or she feels,
  3. health, education, and age factors that may influence attempts to change,
  4. family and work circumstances that may add positive or negative influence, and
  5. how this person views him or herself in their work in terms of performance basics, relationships with their team, and the company policies and procedures.
Develop and use these positive mentoring qualities.
Warm

Greet people, remember important details about them, praise when warranted, and encourage when there is discouragement.

Intelligent

Understand people in their situations in life, be expert in the principles of this program, be able to collaborate with a sense of unity and cooperation, use creative approaches, and invite inspiration from other people.

Strategic

This does not mean manipulative but rather an organized approach connecting effort to desired ends, envisioning the desired change and focusing on it, and organizing action plans a person uses to achieve his or her goals.

Persuasive

Tell stories of great achievements and success, find incentives that work, use language to motivate, and point out strengths that enable a person to believe his or her efforts will bring success.

Pleasant

Believe life is more satisfying than not, enjoy life, appreciate beauty, make hopeful statements, and feel optimistic.

Knowledgeable

Know the principles in this app so well that you can converse positively about them in great detail and understand why they are effective, know the process of change, know the products, know company best practices, and know about people so you can answer their questions.

Positive

The voice of fear and anxiety is always pessimistic. Optimism (or positivity) is a better way to view life; it means finding good things when there is bad, opportunity when there is failure, hope when there is despair.

Firm

Motivate by kindly holding people accountable for what they agreed to do, repeat goal statements, review steps taken to develop positive feelings, and ensure that steps people agree to take are clearly defined and achievable.

Wise

People will trust you if you are calm and collected in response to positive or negative behavior and full of good and helpful facts and ideas. Be willing to allow other people to have good ideas, and make conclusion statements that summarize what people are doing and ratify their efforts to change.

If you are an experienced leader, consider how to use these ideas to better mentor your team. If you are just starting out, you have a great opportunity to develop yourself into a tremendous mentor. As you learn new things, you can quickly identify the type of mentoring that helps you learn and perform better, and then use this perspective to become that type of mentor to your team.

Learn More

content.rendered:
What the Most Successful Leaders Do

Build Capacity

Leadership isn’t given, it’s learned.

Leaders don’t know everything. They aren’t perfect. Leaders are people just like you who develop skills that allow them to transform their mindset, improve their habits, and—most importantly—support and motivate others to achieve more than they ever have before.

Think about the type of leader you would love to work with, and work toward becoming this leader. Start by considering these nine qualities of effective leaders.

1—They are willing to learn from others, but they’re also persuasive.

Effective leaders recognize the value of learning from others. They tend to deflect attention from themselves and think of themselves as neither superior nor inferior to other people and are reluctant to place themselves in positions where they will get more recognition than anyone else. They persuade people by facts, logic, and potential opportunity rather than by aggressive promises.

2—They pursue excellence.

They identify high standards for themselves and others and persistently act to continually improve and encourage others to improve.

3—They are confident enough to stick to something even when it’s difficult.

When a course of action has been selected, successful leaders willfully persist in achieving it even when the going gets tough.

4—They gather and tell success stories.

Successful leaders teach by telling stories. Usually these stories are about what others have done to achieve success, but they also include specific goals and methods of achieving these goals so others may benefit.

5—They focus on the growth of the team.

Ego needs are directed toward the growth of the team and not related to personal fame, reputation, or popularity. Effective leaders are focused on making relationships, internally and externally, for the good and growth of the organization.

6—They implement practices that are not just temporary but are designed for the long-term success of the team.

Effective leaders have a long-term perspective of the impact of any decision. For example, they train new enrollments and place people based on the highest benefit for the team. Their motivations for personal opportunity in the short term either coincide with the goals of the team, or short-term personal goals may be sacrificed for the long-term benefits to the team.

7—They stay focused.

Once committed to a course of action, the most effective leaders display intense resolve to see the goal achieved, a new level obtained, or new practices created.

8—They accept their responsibilities and give credit to others.

When something positive happens, effective leaders give the credit to others and tend to take more responsibility when things go wrong.

9—They work hard.

Effective leaders are diligent, and they tend to be thorough in their efforts. They expect others to be diligent as they create a culture of self-discipline and focus to ensure success.

Learn More

content.rendered:
Congratulations! You made the amazing decision to become an entrepreneur and start helping people. To make this awesome voyage easier and more rewarding, we’ve created Jump Start — a step-by-step guide to helping you develop the skills and mindset to become a confident business leader for yourself and your future team. The proven strategies in Jump Start are what top entrepreneurs and leaders use—so you can build your business with confidence, knowing you are on the right track.

To start fast and more efficiently, make sure you complete a few checklist items if you haven’t already: enroll in the company, enroll in your preferred loyalty program, find and coordinate with a mentor or upline leader, create your account on the company website to gain access to back office tools, and get supplies and product books and resources so you can start becoming expert in the products.

If you have completed these, great. Continue with Jump Start. If you haven’t, do it now because this will make things so much easier and your work more productive and rewarding.

Jump Start is divided into two main sections:

  • Leader Basics will introduce six mindset skills to help you begin the transition into a high-performing leader. Don’t stress about what you do or don’t know. Start right now to think like a leader, and view this transformation as a natural process where you learn and improve, step-by-step.
  • Building Basics will teach you the most successful methods for building your business: time management, identifying what motivates you, setting and achieving goals, contacting, following up, teaching classes, and more.

This business is about caring for and helping other people on your team. You will need to understand both the Leader Basics and Building Basics so you will know how to teach your team, share with them, and lead them.

To help you be better prepared for this type of leadership, you will also be introduced to six leadership methods throughout Jump Start that will help you build stronger, more-prepared, and high-performing teams. The methods in Jump Start are essential to build your business. You can make your efforts more effective and improve your team’s performance by using these proven leadership principles, the natural conditions for high performance:

  1. Foster Trust and Build Teamwork
  2. Define the Direction
  3. Organize a Plan for Innovation
  4. Energize Your Team and Your Alliances
  5. Build Capacity
  6. Measure Progress and Render an Account

Once you complete the Jump Start training, move on to Leader Maker, featuring the Catalyst Leadership System, to apply these skills and discover how to build smarter, stronger, and more successful teams.
